docs.lead_paragraph: Evolution is an excellent teacher when it comes to figuring out what and how much people should eat. For example, primates (including those with two legs and big brains) evolved on foods rich in potassium and very low in sodium. Early humans evolved to conserve sodium, which was hard to obtain, and to excrete excess potassium, abundant in many fruits and vegetables.

headline.main: Preserving a Delicate Balance of Potassium

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column stresses importance of National Academy of Sciences Institute of Medicine report on potassium consumption; risks associated with diet that is too low or too high in potassium described; advantages of eating diet that has ample fresh fruits and vegetables on both overall health and potassium maintenance discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Evolution is an excellent teacher when it comes to figuring out what and how much people should eat.    For example, primates (including those with two legs and big brains) evolved on foods rich in potassium and very low in sodium. Early humans...

docs.lead_paragraph: When a child has a seizure, the family dog may be the first to respond, according to a study released yesterday. The researchers surveyed dog-owning couples who had a child with epilepsy. Almost half said their pets reacted to seizures in specific ways, like licking the child's face. Twenty percent of all dogs in the study were said by the families to be able to tell when seizures were coming, in some cases lying down across the children shortly before convulsions began.
docs.abstract: Dr Adam Kirton of University of Calgary leads research that shows 20 percent of family dogs can detect when child in home is about to have epileptic seizure; study, published in journal Neurology, suggests more research should be conducted on finding; drawing (S)
